title: 106_hr1444
content:
The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" establishes the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program, defining terms like Pacific Ocean drainage area and Secretary of the Interior. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is established within the Department of the Interior to decrease fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems. Projects under the Program may include fish screens, fish passage devices, and other related features to mitigate impacts on fisheries in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program includes projects such as fish screens, fish passage devices, and related features agreed upon by stakeholders. States will provide inventories on project needs and priorities, with priority given to projects costing less than $5,000,000. SEC. 4. PARTICIPATION IN THE PROGRAM.

Non-Federal participation in the Program is voluntary. The Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they apply to participate. Federal projects on US-owned land will not require reimbursement.

SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF PROJECTS.

Projects will be evaluated based on benefits to native fish species, water diversion size, funding availability, cost-effectiveness, and additional biological or water system benefits.

SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. Projects must meet Secretary and State requirements, and have approval from all relevant entities. The Secretary will consult with various agencies and use available data to determine project eligibility. The non-Federal share of costs for projects under the Program on non-Federal land is 35%. Non-Federal participants must provide necessary land, easements, and other resources. The value of these contributions can be credited towards the non-Federal share. Non-Federal participants are responsible for operating and maintaining the project, while the Federal Government has its own responsibilities. The Federal Government is responsible for costs associated with projects on Federal land or at a Federal facility, while non-Federal participants are responsible for operating, maintaining, repairing, rehabilitating, and replacing the project on non-Federal land. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. Projects funded under this Act cannot receive additional Federal funds for the same purpose. 

SEC. 9. REPORT. After three fiscal years, the Secretary must report to Congress on completed projects, those to be finished with remaining funds, and recommended Program changes.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $25,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2001-2005. Limitations: 25% max funds per state, 6% for administrative expenses. Waiver possible for unused funds.
